Detailed Description

A service is an abstract interface which can be accessed by a global unique ID (GUID). The implementation of a service is mostly done by an application, which implements the pure virtual methods of a service.

Accessing a service is done by the ServiceBroker, where each service automatically is registered if available.

A service is meant for communication between applications, where it is not defined which application implements which kind of service. So when an application wants to access a service, it asks whether the service is available at all by invoking

ServiceBroker* broker = ServiceBroker::GetBroker(); if (broker != 0) ServicePtr<MyService> service = broker->GetService(MyService::GUID);

If 'service' is not 0, the service is available and the service methods may get invoked. The benefit of this approach is that one application does not require another application to work. So applications just rely on services: if a service is not available a functionality won't be available, but the application will still work with it's core set.

All implementations of service methods must be implemented in a thread safe manner. It is recommended to implement this by posting messages to the application which implements the service, where the code is executed in the context of the application after receiving the message.

See also:
ServiceBroker
